Design Types: Tools · Clothing and Jewelery · Containers


The most common type of "tool" in most MMORPGs is a weapon. Thus, much of these rules define tools in terms of weaponry. However, this is not to mistake that most of these items have other uses to which they are better dedicated. A piercing item may be a Sage's Quill, while the hammers necessarry for Masons, Miners, and Smiths are blunt objects. A Carpenter's axe may make a fine weapon, but it is still kept because it is useful to his craft.

Base

Cutting

Heft equal the weight of the component materials. Base Damage is one tenth Weight times ten percent of (101 minus the blade's Malleability). Base skill bonuses are per materials used, Quality is 100%, and the item has Durability equal to ten percent of (100 minus Malleability). The weapon's reach in decimeters is equal to its lingth in slots, plus a meter.

Piercing

Heft equal to the weight of the component materials. Base Damage is Weight times one percent of (101 minus the item's Malleability). Base skill bonuses are per materials used, Quality is 100%, and the item has Durability equal to ten percent of (100 minus Malleability) divided by 2 (rounding down). The weapon's reach in decimeters is equal to its lingth in slots, plus a meter.

Blunt

Heft equal to twice the weight of the component materials. Base Damage is one percent of Weight times (101 minus the blade's Malleability). Base skill bonuses are per materials used, Quality is 100%, and the item has Durability equal to ten percent of (100 minus Malleability) times 2. A one-handed weapon's reach in decimeters is equal to its lingth in slots, plus a meter. Two handed, it is half that distance.

Ranged

With Pull; Heft equal twice the weight of the component materials. Base Damage is one half Weight times one percent of (101 minus the weapon's Malleability). Base skill bonuses are per materials used, Quality is 100%, and the item has Durability equal to ten percent of (101 minus Malleability) divided by 2 (rounding down). Pull is equal to the lower of (100 minus Malleability) or Fragility while Range is 1.

Thrown/Ammunition; Heft equal twice the weight of the component materials. Base Damage is ten percent of Weight times five percent of (101 minus the weapon's Malleability). There are no base bonuses, Quality is 100%, and the item has Durability equal to ten percent of (101 minus Malleability) divided by 4 (rounding down). Range is 1.

Modifications

When making the design for an item the character can modify the following aspects of the weapon. All modifications are assumed to be done to create a better weapon than standard. Though a reversal is possible (increasing Heft, reducing Base Damage), this simply creates a bonus instead of penalty or reduces the amount of progress necessarry to complete the item.

Heft

The Heft of the weapon can be decreased to a fraction of the Weight of the component materials. These reductions happen by percentage of the original Heft, each percent reduction increases the difficulty of all crafting checks to create the item by 1.

The minimum Heft of the weapon is 1/4 (Piercing), 1/3 (Slashing), 1/2 (Blunt) the Weight of the weapon. There is no maximum Heft for a weapon.

Base Damage

The Base Damage of an item can be increased. Each point increase increases the difficulty of all crafting checks to create the item by 2.

The maximum increase to base damage is 4x the item's Weight for Blunt weapons or 101-Malleability for Piercing and Cutting weapons. Minimum Base Damage is 0.

Bonuses

Various items are known for granting bonuses to skills, both combat and otherwise. A well made axe can help with the one of the collection specialties of carpentry. Special swords are made to better parry other weapons, or be better second-hand weapons. Some weapons even give non-skill bonuses.

  • Generally, skill bonuses are rated by the amount of virtual Experience they grant in that skill. This experience benefits the character only when equipping that weapon in a way that it can be used, and is lost when the weapon is unequipped or unusable. A 1 point penalty to the crafting skill checks are imposed for each point of experience in a combat skill usable with the weapon, each two points of experience in a non-combat skill, or each three points of experience in a non-combat skill specialization.

Non-skill bonuses have varying values of their own.

Pull

The Pull of a ranged weapon can be increased. Each point increase increases the difficulty of all crafting checks to create the item by 1.

The maximum Pull is 10x the item's Weight, 101-Malleability, or 101-Fragility whichever is lower. Minimum Pull is 0.

Range

Each doubling of the range of an item with Pull increases the difficulty of all crafting checks to create the item by 1.

The maximum number of times Range can be increased for such a weapon is twice the Pull of the weapon, plus one.

If the weapon has no pull (is designed ammunition or to be Thrown) each 1 meter increase in range increases the difficulty of all checks to create the item by 1.

The maximum Range for such a weapon is 10.
